The late, Matuszak plays Jake and Francis' deformed brother, Sloth who befriends Chunk, Green (Summer Rental) plays Andy, a girl Brand gets close with and Plimpton (The River Rat) plays her friend, Stef who join Mikey and the others on their quest. I've liked this 80's classic since I was a kid. It's got a great cast and excellent score by Dave Grusin. I recommend this.

Yeah, I was a kid in the 80's decade and this was one of the first films I've seen since I was about 8, I loved it then and I still love it now. This film is one of my personal favorite films in general.Everything about this film is just perfect (in my book)because it succeeded where most family/kid films fail to do for me which is entertain me, the film kinda manifests that dream we sometimes have of escaping from our usual existence or boredom for a while and going on some wild and fun adventure. It's one of those family/kid movies done the right way where it's not watered down, insult our intelligence, or even pulling off gimmicks just for the sake of it.I really love the set pieces their all practical and built, from the caverns and pirate ship you can really see the effort they put into it. I love the traps which were inspired by the Rube Goalburg cartoons, just seeing how they work is a joy and looks plausible if not entirely probable (some principles work). The music is great that theme song from Cindi Lapper is one of my favorite movie themes. It has good action and suspense that is in constant motion you almost can't take a breath, my favorite is of course the infamous music challenge where the characters have to play a skeleton piano (which looks like something out of heavy metal cover art), that part kept me on the edge of my seat constantly thinking don't you dare hit that wrong note. But the humor is great there are physical gags and verbal humor that beautifully go together, the things you see and hear can be just hilarious, like seeing Brent ride a tricycle sort of the equivalent of the clown bike.But what really makes this film of course are all the characters themselves. There are a lot of protagonists and usually this isn't always a good idea but this film managed to make it work because they all have unique distinctive developed personas where you know them enough but also have a factor of relatibility, I even like that these kids (as well as three teens with them) aren't stereotypical or look like pretty boys/girls(which is a look I can't stand) but looks and feel like regular people. What makes them standout more along with the film is the sense of relatablity, making these protagonists feel more accessible. I even like the location that this film takes place since my aunt, uncle, and cousin live in Oregon state, as well as the neighborhood they live in, looks likes the type I lived in. And all these characters are geeks (I mean that in a good way) and underdogs which I like those kinds of characters because that what I and my friends are, weren't really the kind of kids that were popular but had a lot to offer. I even like their motive for their adventure and it's not for greed or glory which I always believe are the wrong reasons for adventure but simply to save their neighborhood by being demolished by some greedy butt head land developers.As for my favorite character, I'd have to say it's Mouth (played brilliantly by Corey Felman) whom is true to his name. His character is practically the interpreter of the adventure. I just simply love his charisma, he's just funny a real wisecracker, just has some of the best lines in the movie and delivers them well like "Jerk Alert!".The others are great Data whom has as many gadgets as "Batman". Chunk whom despite a big kid, isn't stereotypical he also has some great charisma and lines, he might seem a bit clumsy but by it's nature it's actually dumb luck which really works to his advantage.Brent and Mikey like the back and forth between them how the brotherly relationship is portrayed, kinda similar with the character Pete and Pete in the TV show "The Adv of Pete and Pete". Mikey being the younger one is the most adventious and daring, he's smart but naive. Brent is more grounded, I like the fact even though he's a man of muscle he's not a jock he's an underdog doesn't have a car and probably not much luck with ladies, he gets the most grief from his brother but he goes along (probably also out of boredom) since he has to watch over him even if Mikey is leading him to the road to Hell.Well that's all I have to say, "The Goonies" is a treasure.Rating: 4 stars

I'm not now representative of the film's target audience and not having seen this Steven Spielberg/Richard Donner opus when it came out in 1985 don't have any fond memories of it, but I found 'The Goonies' to be loud, goofy and generally unappealing. A group of young Spielbergesque outcasts set out to find a hidden pirate treasure while being pursued by incompetent crooks. The story doesn't make much sense, the script is long on puerile 'comedy', the characters are either unlikable or uninteresting stereotypes, and the ending mawkishly sentimental (typical of a Spielberg 'kids' film). Maybe I would have liked the film three and half decades ago (but I doubt it).

I don't think I knew a single kid when I was little that didn't have Goonies as one of their favorite movies and I am fairly certain that, today, the adults my age--of the male persuasion--that don't still feel the same are the people that have no since of fun, take everything too seriously, and turn their noses up at the Sabatini collection in their local library.I used to want to live here when I was little. I mean, not only could I be one of the Goonies, but Arnold Schwarzenegger would be my Kindergarten teacher, I could meet Johnny-5, and give a home to Benji.Astoria was a magic place where all your childhood fantasies came true.Especially The Goonies. It was the adventure high of a childhood filled with adventure movies, cartoons, comics, and eventually books.Pirate Treasure, a kid with inventions, bad guys, close friends, a pirate ship, all in the same town that has Kindergarten Cops and robots with lazers.It is literally every kids dream...and unfortunately, like the Ghostbusters, one that will be killed in a remake.DO NOT REMAKE THIS MOVIE. If you want to make money from it, re-release it. DO NOT REMAKE THIS FILM.

As a child of the '80s and '90s, I don't know how I missed "The Goonies" when I was a kid. Was it because it wasn't science fiction or fantasy, the genres I preferred when I was at its target age? I don't know.It's one of those movies that I think is enhanced significantly in the memory of childhood. I doubt anyone who sees it for the first time as an adult would rate it higher than a 6 or 7.The movie is something to do with kids whose house is going to be taken from them by some rich guys who want to build a country club. They find a pirate map in the attic and follow it through some caves to find the treasure. On the way they meet a gang of bad guys led by the inimitable character actress, Anne Ramsey, and other great character actors Joe Pantoliano and Robert Davi. I guess they're just in the movie because it needs a bad guy.The kids in the movie - apparently calling themselves "Goonies" because they live in the "goon docks" area of Oregon - are the usual assortment of colourful characters whose personalities - and usefulness to the plot - can be summed up in one word, and indeed, they are - "Mouth" is the lippy kid, "Data" is the genius whose clothes conceal inventions, "Chunk" is the fat kid. And of course, there's the Average Joe protagonist, because all kids see themselves as average and need someone to identify with.Most of the movie takes place in caves where the Goonies follow a treasure map. This is a tedious location for a kids' movie, and the movie really seems to stall when they get there.In fact, most of the locations in the movie are boring. At least there's a pirate ship at the end. But for most of the run time, I was just waiting for it to end.

When The Goonies was first made the prospect must have been sky high, with a story by Steven Spielberg and him being the Executive Producer, having established director Richard Donner directing, famous for directing the first Superman movie, and had at the time, the young and upcoming Chris Columbus wrote the screenplay.The Goonies tells an simple adventure story where a group of friends are being forced out their neighbourhood because of land-developers wanting to turn their homes in a golf course. Micky (Sean Astin) the leader of the group finds a treasure map and an ancient doubloon leading to a legendary pirate ship underground. They have one day to find it before their homes are foreclosed. Whilst on the hunt for the treasure the Goonies run into the Fratellis, a family of Italian-American criminals. One of them has just escaped from the local jail, Jake (Robert Davi), and the family an abandoned restaurant to counterfeit money. They are not afraid to murder number and go on the chase of the Goonies who could risk their plans.To people who grew up in the 80s and 90s love this film. A number of my friends really like it, and I remember seeing it when I was in Primary School. It is a simply a fun film with action and adventure, with a message of friendship. All the friends have their own character traits, like Mikey as the leader and the most committed to the quest, Mouth (Corey Feldman) as an little trouble maker, Data (Jonathan Ke Quan) the inventor and Chunk (Jeff Cohen) an child who wants to avoid trouble. There is also a good sub-plot involving Mikey's older brother Brand (Josh Brolin) and Andy (Keri Green) who slowly form a relationship during the film. Richard Donner is a good set-pieces director, and he is old-fashioned (and that's a good thing). They is excellent set-designs with good old style action. He used traditional techniques and not things like the birth of CGI and blue screen. He focused on this story and characters. They is a decent screen, and the first did feel a little like Chris Columbus directional efforts towards the Home Alone films. I also the score of the film.The film is not perfect and I did not like the use of proficiency by young kids in this type of film.Still an enjoyable film.

Non stops thrills from Richard Donner and his cast of young stars as they bring to life this adventure film that features Sean Astin as the leader of a pack of "goonies," on the hunt for buried treasure on an old pirate ship. On their journey, they also have to tackle a notorious family of thugs, led by the wonderful Anne Ramsey. It's a fun film for kids and adults alike and features the music of Cyndi Lauper.
Adventure with mostly young cast that is looking for an old pirates treasure. Story and script by Speilberg and Columbus is fun and always entertaining.

Review title: A Wonderful Kid-Friendly Adventure, Essential 80s Viewing Material
Review_body: This one gives me the warmest sense of nostalgia. It's the ultimate '80s kid adventure, as a crew of young pals seek lost pirate treasure beneath their sleepy coastal Oregon suburb. When compared to the stiffer, more highly-orchestrated kids' movies of today, The Goonies is refreshingly grounded. The stakes may be relatively small, but they feel insurmountable from a pre-teen's perspective, and that's what really counts. Led by a sharp-tongued Corey Feldman, the young actors do a great job of conveying that blend of quick wit and fading innocence. They might occasionally trip over words and step on lines, but that makes the production feel more alive, more real. Because, let's be honest, in a room full of actual grade-schoolers, there aren't a whole lot of quiet moments.The opening act, in particular, is a masterpiece of off-the-cuff jokes and effective scene-setting, as we get to know the gang and prepare the stage for their bicycle-powered expedition. Later chapters can get a bit cute, and pacing is sometimes a problem, but those shortcomings are generally smoothed out by the film's convincing practical effects, sweet character and overwhelming sense of childhood discovery. A veritable time capsule of the personalities, and production styles, of the period. And now I've got Cyndi Lauper running through my head again.

Review title: I sort of want to like it but it has aged horribly.
Review_body: As Iconic as this movie is, what i didn't expect was just how weird the pacing is.They are in a big rush to get this story started, such a big one they lay very little groundwork on who the characters are and what the real problem is. I think they're going to lose their home for some reason but I didn't really get a moment to really appreciate what was on stake impressed upon me.Then when they discover a treasure map and they've barely read it before they're out the door like it's nothing. But even after all this rush, it takes a long time for anything interesting to happen. They try and fill the already over stretched running time with sitcom style jokes like how the fat kid likes food or how one kid misleads the monoglot hispanic woman.We get very little impression much interesting is going to happen in what seems, for its first half, to just be some kids, a map and some bank robbers. It picks up eventually with some beautiful sets but boy, does this picture take its sweet time with everything.And everything in this movie is...sloppy. The way the dialogue is formed and how the scenes are visualized...I don't have the vocabulary an actual film scholar would have but I got the impression the the writers and the director were all a bit whatever about the whole thing.I like the child actors, they bring a lot of energy and charisma but they have no idea what enunciation is. I'm not one of these people that needs everything to be in RP to understand english, I speak in RP myself but I struggled to follow them.It's got heart, and I won't say it doesn't have its moments (though half as many as it seems to think it does) but there is a tragic sensation of a real classic that just didn't get the handling it deserved.It's aged quite horribly. If you haven't seen it, even by '80s movies standards it doesn't really hold up, your kids most certainly will not have the patience for it, I know I didn't and I saw it today, in my 20s.At least there is a cute girl and an even cuter one. But the really cute one doesn't kiss anyone...it's a drag.

Plot; With their neighborhood set for demolition to make way for a new golf course, a group of misfit kids set out on one last adventure and get far more than they bargained for.The Goonies is considered a classic by many of my fellow Gen-Xers, but even when I was a kid it never did much for me. By all rights it should've been right in my wheelhouse, but for whatever reason I just didn't feel that connection. Still, I tend to revisit it every five years or so, thinking that maybe those tumblers will finally kick into place. This time they did. Sorta.I'll never regard The Goonies the way I do E.T. or even Joe Dante's flawed Explorers, but this time around I did gain more of an appreciation for it. The kids are all very good here, giving energetic performances and carving out unique and memorable characters in the process. The adults also fare well, with the Fratelli clan (Robert Davi, Joe Pantoliano and Anne Ramsey) making for a fun and eclectic group of villains. It also looks great, from the cinematography to impressive sets like One Eyed Willy's pirate ship. I suppose the thing I enjoyed most was that for 2 hrs. it took me back to being 10 years old, where adventure always seemed just a BMX bike ride away.

Review title: Epic adventure with memorable performances from child actors
Review_body: A group of children go on an adventure to find a pirate's treasure.This is an excellent example of 80s comedy and what works for me is the concept that a group of children can do exciting, 'Indiana Jones' type stuff in their own neighbourhood. This was something I could relate to as a child always seeking to escape the normal town environment and go on adventures into the nearby woods and hills.The plot is reasonably good but is really just a device to kickstart the adventure and provides a reason why it happens.What makes the film great are the Goonies themselves. This movie stars a collection of excited and energetic children. Richard Donner captures distinct characters and some wonderful interaction between them all. That is no mean feet when you have up to seven of them sharing a screen and continuously firing off humorous one-liners. The standout performance is Jeff Cohen who is effortlessly charismatic and funny as Lawrence "Chunk". This type of group is a cliched product of its time, with a leader, a joker, an overweight target, and an ethnic stereotype, but it's about the highest quality example of it you can find.The production values are excellent and stand the test of time, which you would expect from a Spielberg/Donner/Industrial Light and Magic collaboration. The underground sequences are wonderfully atmospheric and the pirate ship is a masterpiece of set design.I was an 80s child and remember The Goonies being almost a cultural movement on the schoolyard due to its popularity. Around about Christmas 1985 you could frequently hear "Hey you guys!" echoing through corridors and witness multiple overweight boys being ritually forced to do the 'truffle shuffle'.

Thanks Spielberg Scary to realize how much of my dialogue is informed by this script. Not a lot of films transport me this well and the Goonies is just so special to me. That moment with data and his dad at the end always has me tearing up.

Review title: One of the best films from my childhood
Review_body: This is one of those few movies from my childhood that still brings a smile to my face. It's an essential adventure flick, filled to the brim with comedy and thrills. No matter how many times you go back to revisit it, the entertainment value is never exhausted.One of my favorite aspects of this film is how real the kids seem. They curse and try to act more adult than they actually are, just as most preteens are wont to do.Anyways, this is an awesome movie. Even though it's dated in some ways (but then again, every movie that ever has been and will be made is going to be dated, even our fancy CG-saturated blockbusters), it holds up very well. Show the kids or treat yourself.

Review title: High Spirited adventure is both fun for the kids and the adults.
Review_body: After the escape of a convict (Robert Davi) in a small town, helped by his mother (Anne Rasmey) and his brother (Joe Pantoliano). On that same day, Several families are devastated that they are losing their homes. Since the rich are turning their homes into a golf course. An young 13 year old boy (Sean Astin) discover a map that could lead to the missing treasure from a missing pirate ship. Now with the help of his brother (Josh Brolin) and their friends (Corey Feldman, Jeff Cohen, Kerri Green, Martha Plimpton and Ke Huy-Quan) embark to a unforgettable adventure but they ended up being followed by criminals, who also wants the missing treasure.Directed by Richard Donner (The Omen, 16 Blocks, Superman:The Movie) made an amusing, fun adventure for the young and old. This was one of the biggest hits of 1985. This is high energy film, which it was consider as mess by some critics. If "The Goonies" is a mess, it is an entertaining mishmash.DVD has an sharp anamorphic Widescreen (2.35:1) transfer an fine, digitally remastered-Dolby Digital 5.1 Surround Sound. DVD's best feature is the commentary track by the director and the cast. which they are seen in the commentary on video at several moments. DVD includes Deleted Scenes, Behind the Scenes featurettes, original theatrical trailer and a two part music video. This movie is still playing well for over 20 years and it become an family classic for those who grown up watching the film and also finding new audiences on DVD. Steven Spielberg (Who directed a few scenes in the picture) is one of the executive producers. Written by Chris Columbis (Gremlins, Mrs. Doubtfire, Bicentennial Man). From a story by Spielberg. Panavision. (****/*****).

Review title: I will never betray my Goon Dock friends
Review_body: For me, this is one of the 80s adventures I loved as a kid that doesn't hold up. Watching it as an adult, I still liked the characters, but just didn't get caught up in the story. Speaking of the characters, it really does have a great cast, and I think that is what most people must be fond of. The kids are fun, but throw in Mama Fratelli and Sloth, and you've got a pretty memorable experience. It is never less than entertaining, and I think that quality does hold up.
Great kids movie and it is a shame that movies like this aren't made anymore. Great journey with a lot of fun and with some adult messages.

Fun, light "Indiana Jones" for kids is this story from Steven Spielberg, adapted to the screen by Chris Columbus. Stars up and coming actors of the time including Sean Astin, Josh Brolin, Corey Feldman, Ke Huy Quan and Martha Plimpton. Also starred Joe Pantoliano and the wonderful Anne Ramsey.Richard Donner directs (why is anybody's guess) this journey into fantasy as a group of young kids stumble through caves and booby traps in search of legendary treasure. "The Goonies" has all the ingredients to thrill the younger ones, with scary villains, thrilling traps and an amiable cast. For adults: don't expect the greatest adventure film ever.Theme "Goonies 'R' Good Enough" came from Cindi Lauper. Remember her?Friday, February 20, 1998 - Video

Review title: One of the Best Family Movies
Review_body: Within an hour from seeing The Goonies at the local cinema, I was in the back yard of my house with a shovel looking for buried treasure. Even though I was in Massachusetts and had no clue of any pirates had been there in the past 400 years, I was determined to find "One Eye" Willies treasure behind my house. Seeing this movie for the first time at the age of 8, I was one of millions of kids who were blown away by this Family action / comedy.A modern day fantasy that is still as good when it came out almost 20 years ago, the story of beating the odds, good verse evil, finding hope in the most unlikely of places, the under dogs winning the day, and the age old take of discovery is what Goonies is all about. An interesting cast which makes the movie, the story is an adventure of youth and exploration, even though they never leave their home state. A terrific movie for the entire family.

For a short time in my life, The Goonies was the greatest movie ever made. While I'm older and have different tastes, I have no problem sitting through it on television or whenever my friend wants to watch it. Unfortunately, "kiddie" films like this aren't made with this kind of passion anymore.Granted, Spy Kids may have reestablished this medium, but that film didn't have the dialogue and wit The Goonies possessed. Its hard to say something like this, but this film is definitely one of a kind.

Review title: The Cyndi Lauper Nostalgia Machine still rocks...
Review_body: Before tonight, it had been roughly 7 years since my last viewing of "The Goonies" (from an era where I bore the nickname 'Sloth' among a select few)...and at first, I didn't really know what to think. The hyperactive exclamations of prepubescent Sean Astin ('Mikey'), Corey Feldman ('Mouth'), Jeff Cohen ('Chunk'), and Ke Huy Quan ('Data')--the 'Goonies' of the title--kind of grated on my nerves with their novice, kitchen-sink performances (even considering the usual excesses of child actors, this was pushing it). But just as I was beginning to think that, the movie kicked into gear and began its enthralling course--yes, even at 25 years of age, I can say without a hint of shame that I had a lot of fun with this kid-friendly "Temple of Doom." Our titular characters live in an overcast seaside community, set to be razed by greedy land developers looking to put up a golf course. While messing around with the antiques in Mikey's attic, our boys stumble across a 17th-century treasure map, and decide to embark on a quest to find the (implied) riches contained within. In their travels, they also run afoul of the slapstick quartet of 'Ma' Frattelli (Ann Ramsey) and her three sons (Robert Davi and "Memento"'s Joe Pantoliano), one of whom is a hideously deformed--but very humane--Charles Addams caricature. The Goonies also run into booby traps aplenty, and the story maintains a surprising amount of unpredictability, considering its target audience (while *mostly* a kid's movie, the material isn't inaccessible to older viewers).That being said, Steven Spielberg's story credit seems a bit dubious, especially when looking at "The Goonies" from a distance: he could have very well approached Warners with "'Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom,' only with kids instead of Harrison Ford!" and collected his check on the way out. Whereas Indy, Willie, and Short Round altruistically braved peril to save the children of an impoverished Indian village, we have the Goonies altruistically banding together to save their threatened community.Of course, this would be bothersome...if "The Goonies" wasn't so much damn fun. Like the endearing classic "Ghostbusters," "The Goonies" is a similar 1980s gem, with a sense of creativity, adventure, and humor (including some fine one-liners), with plenty of crossover appeal to individuals who claim to have 'outgrown' this sort of film. If the film is dated in any way, it's only in the Cyndi Lauper theme song (which is still a bitchin' tune) that gives "The Goonies" its adventurously fun, young-at-heart identity.

I didn't realise how highly I rated this film until I tried to compare it to the other 700 films that I have reviewed and rated over the past couple of years. It's just got a lot to it. There's a cause to fight for, humour in buckets, adventure, terror, crime and romance all encapsulated in a great little story and with performances from some of the best child actors of the eighties.As a child of the eighties myself, it will always have a little nostalgic place in my heart that will remind me to revisit it and often. One of those films that you should definitely share with your own children, grandchildren, nieces and nephews and anyone else who hasn't seen it basically. It sounds like a cliche, but they really don't make them like this anymore. Mostly because they wouldn't get away with it.It is a fantastically funny film with slapstick that doesn't hit you too hard, as well as jokes of a more subtle nature, with something that everyone can enjoy. I love the cartoon sound effects that they used.I can't help but wonder how much of this film was improvised or just what the cameras caught while they were still rolling, as it looks like the cast has a fantastic time making it and there are some bits that are just too brilliant to have been scripted.One of the only issues I have with the film, which I have carried with me since I first saw it, is Sloth. That guy still scares the bejesus out of me even now. I mean, why did they have to make his ears wiggle like that??? To be honest the entire Fratelli family are pretty scary. You certainly wouldn't want to meet them in a dark alley.The only other flaw that I can find, which is true of many films of a similar kind, is that they all shout and talk over each other and it makes it impossible to hear what's going on.Apart from that, this film will always be a classic and should be a marker that all children's adventure flicks should be held up against.

The Goonies is yet another 80s teen/youth targeted movie that will transcend its time for years to come. In fact, I had just gone to a free screening of The Goonies in the park and the audience was primarily people in their early and mid 20s. So it looks like the people who loved this movie as a kid will cherish even as they get older. I'm one of them. As one of the greatest adventure film, The Goonies were a group of kids out of the Oregon boonies (aka The Goondocks). The Walshes who's son, Mikey (Sean Astin), is the unofficial Goonies leader, knows that his folks need plenty of cash fast to cover the back taxes and save the Goondocks from the like of that sniveling Troy Perkins's father.Hanging around the house one afternoon and driven by the curiosity of what Mikey's father might do with all that cool junk in the attic, the boys come upon a great discovery: a map of One-Eyed Willy's (yes, there are obvious synonyms to be made from the name) "rich stuff." So The Goonies are on one last adventure!Only, the map leads them to a bunch of fugitive gangsters called The Fratelli's (a terrific cast of villains featuring Anne Ramsey as Mama Fratelli; Joe Pantoliano as Francis; Robert Davi as Jake; and the late John Matuszak as the large, deformed and loveable Sloth Fratelli). When one of the Goonies get's captured by the Fratelli's, it doesn't take them long to figure out that these kids are sniffing a trail of treasure, and the Fratelli's want to get to it first, no matter what.Aside from a great story and a great soundtrack (featuring 80s queen, Cindi Lauper in the soundtrack and music video for the song, 'Good Enough'), you have a priceless cast and film crew. Sean Astin, Josh Brolin, Martha Plimpton, and Corey Feldman (to some extent) have surpassed their transition into adult roles, so they've been around quite a while. Nostalgic viewers should get a kick out of seeing them a squeaky voice little kids--except for the gorgeous Josh Brolin, who was already 17 at the time of the film's release. None of the kids are annoying as those cast in family films often tend to be (and with the exception of some of Sean Astin's dialogue, it is hardly corny). You have a good assortment of characters like fast-talking Mouth (Corey Feldman), braniac inventor (Data), and the hyperactive fat kid (who may be the most well known character in the film and turned Jeff Cohen into a cult star, despite his not doing much in movies afterwards).
And of course, it is especially helped by filmmakers who always work well with family film material and young casts and scripts (like Speilberg with E.T.; and Chris Columbus with Home Alone and the Harry Potter movies), especially when it comes to the adventure genre. This movie really has a lot going for it and gives a lot of laughs from beginning to end.
Kids will surely enjoy this great modern pirate adventure! If you're a kid, it probably encourages you to seek out some Goonie adventure yourself, afterwards.

Review title: Dashes of Spielberg magic, but the characters sorta annoy me
Review_body: As a kid I've never bothered to watch "The Goonies", which according to most definitions of the term means I haven't had a childhood. Today I've finally made up for lost time, but unfortunately I was a tad disappointed. The story about a bunch of kids trying to trace a pirate's treasure has all the potential in the world, but all this old trilobite got out of this movie was a migraine. There's so much high-pitched screaming going on in this movie I've turned on my alarm clock just to relax a little. And generally I have nothing against stereotypes, but come on: 80% of the fat kid's lines is about food, the Asian kid invents gadgets, it's just sorta painful here. Why these characters get so much attention while the at the time still cool Corey Feldman barely gets to do anything is beyond me. The movie's obviously well-made and it definitely has some bright spots (Sloth!), but you just miss the heart-warming friendship between boys you saw in things like "Stand By Me" or "The Lost Boys". Not my cup of tea.

Review title: Required 80s for Kids Growing up Then
Review_body: As a child to teenager growing up in the 80's this was a memorable one. I remember really enjoying it when I was 9 walking out of the theater. One of the definitive 80s movies, The Goonies, a mid-80s movie pretty much defines the decade and adventure genre. Not really an important movie or particularly well done, it features some fun scenes and memorable chumming awash in perfectly 80s music. The cast of child actors seemed to mesh very well, obviously enjoying their moments together. The adventure is well paced, if standard, and the sets are fairly well done for the most part. Yes, The Goonies is one of those movies, you may stop to watch if you see it again for nostalgia's sake if you're one of those 80s kids. Recommended for 80's fans especially.

Review title: A nostalgic, timeless and powerful classic
Review_body: I can still remember my dad putting a VHS tape of this movie on when I was a kid, I loved it! The title and initial intro was slightly off-putting but it's one of those movies that you have to watch the whole thing of to really appreciate it. Sure, it's a little weird at times, there's a few crude jokes (the statue, oh my god), but at a closer look you'll see that it's a story about friendship and childhood adventures, something you never get too old to remember.The Goonies is one of those films that either you love, or you hate. I love it and I hope it isn't lost among the sea of bad remakes of other movie classics popping up in the 21st century. I hope other generations get to experience this film (though at that point it may be outdated since kids today are lazy as heck and slaves to Apple Inc.). This movie is somewhat of a cult film, it has a fanbase of people who grew up with it and love it and it's becoming more popular as a nostalgic relic.

'The Goonies' is more than anything else a hysterical movie; almost every character seems to be screaming most of the time. And quite a few characters are pretty annoying even beyond that, like Chunk (didn't he look like Bette Midler's grandson?) and his obsession with food, Mikey (Sean Astin? Really? I hadn't recognized him) and his ability to be utterly corny to the point one would call a doctor, or Mouth, who is just plain annoying. The plot itself is like Indiana Jones for kids, without the traveling, plus a dysfunctional Italian crime family.Nearing the end, things got better, with the dazzling water slide and that terrific underground set with the pirate ship (though that town and its surroundings were great to look at as well). One character who was over the top also, but still has my sympathy, is Sloth. Mother Fratelli, by Anne Ramsey, was quite 'lovable', too. All in all, a kid's film that is just about doable if you can take all hysteria, though I'd expected to feel more sentimental than I do.6 out of 10.

Review title: It takes a lot of work to look this effortless... and fun.
Review_body: I guess if Evil Dead gets 37 different DVD releases and practically every film released in the last decade has three or four versions on sale, it's only fair that The Goonies gets a special 25th anniversary edition DVD release. After all this teen Indiana Jones featuring the pre-pubescent Breakfast Club holds a similar place for as many 30 somethings as Stand By Me does, and like Stand By Me this film holds up remarkably well.If you were going to make a movie that appeals to teenage boys what do you think you might put in it?Bikes, inventions, skeletons, nutshots, potty humour.Adventure, near misses and close escapes? Booby traps, codes and challenges.Criminals? Monsters??TREASURE MAPS & PIRATES???How about all of the above? The Goonies are four pre-teen buddies with clever nicknames that also serve to explain more about them than 15 minutes of exposition would:Mouth – The loud talkative one.Data – The nerdy inventor one.Chunk – The fat obnoxious and clumsy one.Mike – The ummm one named Mike? He is asthmatic if that helps.The first prison escape and ensuing car chase neatly intros every principal character that will appear in the film within an entertaining 5 minutes. Clever stuff really.After a couple more rambunctious pre-teen conversations – and a plot device that finds them with the desperate need to find big cash quick or their house will be foreclosed to make way for a golf course – the boys unexpectedly come across what appears to be a pirate's treasure map from 1632, made by the renowned local pirate One Eyed Willie (aren't they all?).So the four Goonies, along with Mike's older brother Brandon (Josh Brolin Yep No Country for Old Men himself) and his cheerleader target of (PG13) conquest Andie and her buddy Steph unwittingly along for the ride; off everyone goes for an adventure.To ramp up the action a notch further the local crime family the Fratellis are injected into proceedings so that they might pose a threat by staying one step behind the kids at all times. Don't worry kids, the Fratellis are an old Mum and her two boneheaded sons, no-one gets hurt and there is never any serious peril or danger.With all the major players identified and in play the hunt leads all and sundry into a vast underground series of caves and tunnels, with booby traps and dangerous terrain all around, the traps were lain by the late Mr Willie who it was alleged would rather die wealthy than spread his booty around unlike Jessica Simpson – who will only die wealthyEach Goonie gets their respective chance to shine as they come across each new obstacle or elaborate puzzle, the girls are their to provide love and lust interests and to shriek when the situation demands – and if all that isn't enough a fourth "forgotten" Fratelli, the hideously disfigured ogre-ish Sloth pops his magnificently unique lump head into the fray Again don't worry he's not a bad hideously disfigured, massively muscled ogre, he's a good guy (great 80s makeup job though!).Everyone learns something from the experience, there is some immensely entertaining action sequences and the whole thing is as light and realistic as a Miss Universe contestant, thankfully it makes more sense though.What sets Goonies apart is the little touches, despite the large number of characters in the group everyone is distinctly different, but aside from just the broad strokes mentioned above there are little touches that lend further human qualities to the boys that go beyond mere caricature – the asthma inhaler, the inventions, the clumsiness and strange stories – they all help.The plot is necessarily preposterous at all times, everything is skewed towards fun and escapism, and as mentioned previously this has been purpose built to entertain, amuse and inspire young boys – just like Britney Spears. That's three pop-culture potshots at obvious targets in one review – my parents must be so proud!Final Rating – 7.5 / 10. As with many things The Goonies all appears effortless and straightforward, but as we should know it takes a lot of effort and planning to make things look this easy, even then this has the added bonus of being consistently fun and engaging. There's a reason this has an audience 25 years on when Due Date will be forgotten in 25 days.

'The Goonies' is one of those films that everybody has seen at least once in their lifetime and is something of a guilty pleasure for many. It's a rarity in that, although it's a kids film through and through, it goes down just as well (if not better) with adults.As someone who was born after 'The Goonies' was released, I don't have the same fond memories of this film as others who grew up with it do. For me, it's an imaginative and enjoyable family adventure, but not the 'classic' that it is to others. 'The Goonies' has some great individual moments and scenes but as a whole, I think there are better kids adventure films out there.

It was in 2001 or thereabouts that I watched and listened to the audio commentary track that is on the DVD version of The Goonies. Nostalgia is a wonderful thing, and seeing how the principal cast had aged (or hardly aged in Josh Brolin's case) was worth the price of admission on its own. But this is just one of The Goonies' selling points. Despite what the IMDb's ratings would have you believe, it is an immortal classic that warrants repeated and frequent viewings. It is not a coincidence that many of its cast and crew have repeatedly appeared in all sorts of productions before and since. Indeed, this was probably the first film that introduced me to the reality that the same actor will often play ten different parts in ten different films when I realised that Jonathan Ke Quan was the same brat that made parts of Indiana Jones And The Temple Of Doom so amusing. Seeing him in the video-enhanced commentary of the DVD nearly two decades later was a surprise and a half.The film revolves around a group of children and adolescents who live in the poorer, less trendy part of a beachfront town. Unlike an episode of Barney, every member of this principal group is given a background and a string of differences from their castmates. You will not see the teenaged Brand responding to the same situation in the same manner as the ten year old Mikey, and that is where a major part of the film's strength is derived. The only weakness in the characterisations is with Martha Plimpton and Kerri Green, who join the adventuring boys a little way into the film. Exactly what they are doing other than giving the character of Brand something similar to himself to bounce his more adult-oriented lines from is anyone's guess, but they do work in their limited capacity. It is just a pity that Chris Columbus' screenplay did not give them a little more to do, other than defuse one fiendish trap towards the end of the ride.Speaking of fiendish traps, the adventurers journey from one puzzling location to the next with barely a stop for breath. It works because unlike similar adventure films where the director expects us to be impressed by a fiendish-sounding name, the specific places that are visited by the Goonies have function. The bone piano shown in one such sequence, for example, would appear in the nightmares of children learning a regular piano for years after the film's theatrical release. It also gives Corey Feldman a good chance to act out a character who speaks very fluent Spanish. And while I am on that subject, who could forget the immortal scene early on in the film where Mouth deliberately loses something in the translation when Rosalita is shown around? But the prize for scene-stealing goes to John Matuszak, who plays the unofficial eighth Goonie, Sloth, with a weird aplomb that may well scare the willies out of parts of the intended audience. But then, in 1985, scaring the intended audience a little was considered a healthy part of making a film for those in the age ranges depicted here.They say you cannot have a good protagonist without a good antagonist to bounce off. Robert Davi, Joe Pantoliano, and Anne Ramsey provide antagonists so good that they utterly hose the rule about not working with animals or children. The Fratellis work so well here because they are working with children. The late Anne Ramsey played her part so well that the mere thought of watching her in anything scared the willies out of me for years. Nowadays, as I have fully realised the mechanics behind film for some years, I am keen as mustard to see some of her other work in such pieces as Throw Momma From The Train (now there's a title that brings images to mind) or Meet the Hollowheads. That a performance can produce two entirely different reactions in the same person at different stages of their life should tell you all you need to know about its quality. Robert Davi and Joe Pantoliano are somewhat overshadowed here, but the manic, cackling quality of their introductory act also left quite a lasting impression.You might have noticed that I have so far only mentioned the special effects in passing while heaping praise upon the acting. This is because unlike films such as the recent Star Wars prequels, the effects complement the acting rather than overshadow it. From what I am able to tell, all of the effects in The Goonies are practical, and some of them quite inventive. There is no use of blood squibs, which may disappoint some viewers, but there are enough mechanical sets and air vents to fill three films. Some of these effects did not turn out so well and were cut from the final film (the squid sequence being the most famous example), but unlike a lot of films that depend on special effects for a crucial element, everything shown in the final cut is in perfect sync here. Suspension of disbelief is never an issue, which is just as well considering some of the preposterous things that roll by the screen with a certain nonchalance.I gave The Goonies a ten out of ten. Like Superman or the original Lethal Weapon, it shows that Richard Donner knows how to make a classic. Now that it is twenty years old, it stands forever as a relic of a time when the world of those under the age of eighteen was far less oppressive. If you have not introduced your children around the age of ten or greater to its joys and moments, then shame on you.

The Goonies is a childhood adventure best left to children. Kids might find the movie enjoyable. Maybe. But viewed through the eyes of an adult the movie is a flop. The script is dire, the acting is rather terrible, a number of the characters serve no purpose while other characters serve only to annoy. And the supposed great adventure our young heroes go on is not even particularly interesting. There is very little excitement to be had here, honestly this is a rather boring movie.The story follows a group of kids as they search for long-lost pirate treasure. A very simple plot but that would be OK if this treasure hunt was exciting. It is not. The kids find many obstacles in their way. There are booby traps to get through and some hapless villains on their tail. It all becomes repetitive rather quickly. Make your way through this trap, then that trap, then another trap. All along the way spout terrible dialogue and in many instances have many kids spouting that terrible dialogue all at the same time. These kids talk, and scream, over one another for two hours. Get me an aspirin. The acting is completely unconvincing. Child actors are capable of great performances. Not in this movie. We get grating performances from the whole lot of them. Sean Astin, playing the leader of the group, is probably most annoying of all though Ke Huy Quan, who you may remember as the incredibly annoying kid from Temple of Doom, runs him close. There are a couple of girls tossed into the proceedings and they add absolutely nothing. Meanwhile the villains are total duds. There is very little good to say here. This is one dull, empty adventure.

This film still holds up after all these years.A group of misfit kids set out to find a pirate's buried treasure in order to save their homes from being turned into a golf course. What follows is like an Indiana Jones adventure for tween boys. To make matters worse they are being pursued by the criminal Fratelli family who also want the treasure.What will happen? Will the kids survive, find the treasure or meet their end at the hands of the Fratellis?This movie does not disappoint. Nostalgia for those that have seen it before. Fantastic Fun. Worth repeated viewings!

When he learns his family are to be relocated away from their home, Mikey (Astin) and his friends The Goonies set out on one last adventure to find a Pirate's lost treasure.The stars of tomorrow. The kids are out future. Whatever expression you choose, it can be applied to this good natured romp that sees modern day stars in their opening roles.Sean Astin, who leads the way splendidly, would soon be hailed to fail in the Lord of the Rings trilogy whilst Josh Brolin would take up award winning roles in No Country for Old Men.But of course this was the time before such accolades and so we settle for more subdued but more fun style acting in a charming adventure that has the energy and mystery of an Indiana Jones adventure, if not the sophisticated mythology and independence.The opening scenes see a charming if highly unrealistic prison breakout that starts our adventure off in thrilling fashion. Followed sweetly by the sharp and memorable introduction of The Goonies and you'll be forgiven for smiling from ear to ear. Jonathan Ke Quan's introduction is one to not be spoiled, but watch out for never has a young actor made such an exciting appearance.As we have a political message thrown in and some sloppy information encoded for historical emphasis, we are finally under way with the group setting off on an adventure to recover the treasure of One Eyed Willie. The idea sounds absurd, and in many degrees it is. In context the whole idea of getting treasure to save their house seems far-fetched and a last ditch attempt but thankfully we can almost ignore the obscurity of this goal and simply sit back and enjoy the thrills and comedy spills along the way.There are some marvellous set pieces juxtaposed with stunning semiotics of piracy. The boat itself is a symbol of true fantasy gold and the sweeping set montages do justice to the story's potential. The action and adventure side, whilst Indiana Jones obstacles, is nonetheless fun and exciting and true gold for the younger viewers.When combining two such different genres in comedy and adventure it is easy to give one away to the other but somehow writer Spielberg and director Donner maintain both in equal balance, which is a stunning achievement given the complexity of different personalities of The Goonies and the massive adventure on hands, which makes this a wonder in itself.Where The Goonies falls is it's lack of realism in context. There are too many close calls and just in time moments and there seems to be lacking any real consequence, maybe because the characters are kids to give the viewers a more relaxed viewing.But this 1985 release is visually stunning, balancing the genres on equal length and when the laughs come, they really do. It's no Indiana Jones substitute but it is a smash

Review title: A cult classic that I couldn't get into.
Review_body: Cult classics are intriguing films. I feel there is a lot of nostalgia tied to a movie that hits a generation of individuals at just the right time for them to be memorable to these people. Sometimes, these cult classics are movies that I didn't get around to seeing-especially when they were relevant to my friends. For whatever reason, The Goonies (1985) has eluded me for 35 years. I can certainly see its appeal, but I mostly just watched it and wondered why people thought it was so great.I will say that this film is a trip down memory lane in the sense that I don't think I've ever seen a movie with either Sean Astin or Josh Brolin as young as they were in this one. The fact that many meme-able moments from this film have lasted in the popular culture zeitgeist for so long is a testament to its powerful nostalgia. Having never seen The Goonies until now, I already knew it was about pirate treasure and the adventure a rag-tag group of kids embarks on to recover it.All this being said, The Goonies is weird. I felt like its first act dragged along, and it didn't get interesting until about half-way through (when it entered its Indiana Jones phase). Plus, there were almost too many subplots that seemed to be included to pad the run-time on an already light plot. Sure, each of the kids had their own adventure along the way, but did it need to include "Sloth" (John Matuszak)? If anything, I found The Goonies to be a bit insensitive to the disabled, as well as to Asians-with the Asian stereotype being played for laughs more often than not.A cult classic that I couldn't get into, I give The Goonies 3.0 stars out of 5.
The greatest segment is the one where Mama gets thrown in the water by her adopted son!!!

Review title: A Fast-Paced Adventure For All Ages!
Review_body: As a child, I loved The Goonies. The movie seemed to be a rite of passage for every kid growing up in the 80's, 90's, and even today. The movie appealed to me because it has treasure hunts! I mean, what kid does not want to go on a treasure hunt? As an adult, I was ready to dive back into the world of nostalgia. The end result? In terms of Spielberg-produced adventures, I did like Gremlins more. That does not mean I disliked this particular movie or anything. It is a fun, highly-energized adventure film with all of those Spielbergian trademarks we all come to know and love. I think I outgrew the main characters. They had wonderful chemistry and acted like normal children, but perhaps I was a little annoyed with them.Steven Spielberg did not direct the movie, only merely produced it. He oversaw the production, however. Spielberg was one of those innovators who introduced "horror films for children", the trend that grew massive starting in the 1980's. He took horrifying concepts and made them kid-friendly, and more fun. These films, while still a little scary, allowed children and adults alike to enjoy the film. Like Gremlins and Ghostbusters, The Goonies is one of those films. This film also was influenced by the first two Indiana Jones films. You see the falling boulders and the sharp spikes. As for the children themselves, I did see ET influences. For the most part, I think the influences were incorporated rather well into the film.The film was helmed by Richard Donner, who previously directed one of my favorite superhero films, Superman. This shoot was a new challenge for Donner because he worked with kids. He later mentioned the positive and negative aspects for working with children on set. In a sense, he was a teacher for these kids. I think Donner did an excellent job, because making these sort of films is not easy. As for the screenplay, it was written by Chris Columbus, who makes a living with these kind of scripts. Columbus did understand past Spielberg works pretty well.Mikey Walsh (Sean Astin) and his brother, Brand (Josh Brolin) live in a family that is being forced to move in order for a new golf course to be built...unless money is somehow raised to save their home. Mikey happened to stumble across a treasure map depicting a vast fortune hidden away. The two brothers along with rest of the "Goonies" gang; Chunk (Jeff Cohen), Mouth (Corey Feldman), Andy (Kerri Green), Stef (Martha Plimpton), and Data (Ke Huy Quan), set out to recover this fortune. Their adventure takes them to the evil Mama Fratelli (Anne Ramsay) and her three sons including the disfigured Sloth (John Matsuzak) who decides to help them. In order to find the treasure, they need to find a way past the Fratellis. Goonies never say die!The cast is filled with young blood who will go on to have excellent careers; namely Sean Astin, Josh Brolin, Joe Pantoliano (one of the Fratelli brothers), and Martha Plimpton. As for this particular film, the performances are fine. The kids definitely have energy to no end, but it can grow stale after awhile. The chemistry between the kids is great and it really feels like they have a bond, which I absolutely loved as a kid. I get why everyone loves Chunk, but I felt his character is too melodramatic and a little annoying. The Fratelli's are moronic villains, but there is a reason why they are everyone favorite's villains. Anne Ramsay, although a little over-the-top, is really fun to watch.Once The Goonies start a-rolling, the action and the thrills do not stop. Some people point out that this film has more to it than most action films. Whether or not that is to your liking will depend on your tastes. The film is loaded with special effects. Some are good, and some...not too good. The music plays well with the film as Cyndi Lauper actually delivered a hit song thanks to the movie. As a child, this film will satisfy your every dream. It has pirate ships, evil cooks, and the sense of adventure. As an adult, this will all depend on your patience. Although I cannot consider the movie a magic-inducing phenomenon it was when I was a kid, I still enjoyed this fast-paced adventure.My Grade: B

Although little is known today about this film, it seems that every time I see it seems better, a true masterpiece of cinema. This movie is a true 80's classic that everyone should watch at least once in their life, with a truly good story, full of good jokes, good special effects, good characters and an argument that grabs the story to the end and that will make you see the movie over and over again. Very good, highly recommend.

Review title: One of the funniest, best films of my childhood
Review_body: I think that nearly everyone who grew up in the 1980s has seen this film at some point. When I think of 'The Goonies', I am always brought back to my childhood. This is a very 1980s film, and it is very nostalgic for those of us who grew up with it. I would even say that this is one of the best films of my childhood. It had virtually everything going for it: treasure maps, kids in control of their destinies, pirate ships, deformed and misunderstood Sloth, humour with outcast and overweight Chunk, revenge, 'booby' traps, evil/creepy Italians, and I could go on and on. There's a lot this film has going for it, and its highly engaging plot ensures that children will not be bored. Even, it is a little bit silly. The kids make this film what it is, and they are the ones that save the day. They outsmart the evil Fratellis and get the treasure. And, who could not find the scenes with Sloth and Chunk highly amusing, especially when Chunk confesses everything that he has done wrong? This is a pure gem. Very good, and it still brings back laughter into my 20s.

1980's adventure classic that brings pirate legend into 20th century Astoria, OR. A group of preteens stumble upon clues of a lost treasure nearby and decide to go on one last adventure before their homes are torn down to help expand a country club. Nostalgic but also timeless, offering enough originality to make it memorable while also sticking fairly close to the typical treasure hunt adventure. The character development gives off the feeling like there were so many adventures before and so many more to come but, behold, only one movie was ever made. Ramsey is always a terrific villainess, while Davi and Pantoliano have the right/intentionally-wrong chemistry as her two convict sons who are more interested in bickering and fighting for their mother's love than following the trail of the Goonies. Then we have the side-story of Chunk (Cohen) and Sloth (Matuszak), a duo that is worthy enough to have their own spin-off. Cyndi Lauper's song is also very fitting.***½ (out of four)

The first time I saw THE GOONIES was at a friend's house right when it was a "new release" on video. After the best times I had in my life watching it, the friend established a "Goonie" club for the fun of it. Perhaps your past childhood memories would have been the same, too! While the movie is a tad heavy on the stupid foul jokes, it does have the imagination of willing to trek around for some perilous adventures, plus a few spooks. There possibly was never a movie like this providing tons of fun and laughter during the time. The characters and their personalities were most original, including "Data" and his supply of gadgets, and "Chunk" with his obese but likeable image (love that "Truffle Shuffle"!). But "Sloth" easily stole the show with his own likeable personality, a goon with the weirdest face I've ever seen in my life! Just think of how fun it is to discover lost treasure, when you know it's only fantasy. Four key things come to mind with THE GOONIES: pirate ships, teenagers, the Frattellis, and Cyndi Lauper. They're actually "good enough" and they go together in this memorable journey! Kudos to Richard Donner for bringing me a movie that I've seen over 100 times and never stop enjoying! After all these years, I'm STILL waiting for a sequel!HIT PUREE!!!

I went to see Goonies on the big screen back in 2019 for it's 34th anniversary 4K screening. As someone who wasn't around in 85 to watch it getting to see it on the big screen in this generation was a dream come true.The movie still holds up as one of the best movies made and today still inspires people and makes people smile.It is well shot and the cast is perfect as a band of kids known as the goonies hunt for a lost treasure to save there homes it's a great adventure for all ages and is a true classic.If by some miracle you haven't already seen this masterpiece watch it and join the Goonies around the world who love this classic tale.

This is one of my favourite adventure movies of all time. Everything about it is brilliant from start to finish. I remember first watching this being shown on Channel Five in England, and was very excited in watching this - it was enjoyable.In fact, "The Goonies" is one of these rare movies that looks better to watch when on television if that makes any sense - that's the impression I seem to get. There's seems to be some nostalgia about it, maybe.Things do begin to start of pretty slowly, but it does finally start picking up the pace later, as the movie progresses, and that's a good thing because the movie gets more and more interesting. The story was brilliant, and easy to understand, a wonderful adventure.The great thing about "The Goonies" is that you, the viewer, are always on the kids' side, and are supporting on their goals and adventure, and hope that they sail all the way through; In other words, you actually want them to win, but it seems like the movie actually gives you the impression that they won't.It seems like this movie is a bit unpredictable, and I think that's a good thing. Yes, it's a family, adventure and comedy film, but it's clearly a lot more than that.This movie, sometimes, doesn't get the appreciation it deserves. The rating on IMDb testifies to that. It has a rating just under eight which is still fantastic, but you would think a movie such as "The Goonies" would have a rating well pass that, and I don't understand why it doesn't because there's nothing the movie could've done wrong. So, I'm actually surprised by the overall rating for this film.It was also released in the eighties too, and there weren't too many wonderful family films back then, as compared to the nineties, where there were plenty. The vast majority of them I don't think can match up to "The Goonies" I feel.There has been talks of a sequel even till today, and whether it's a good thing that it hasn't happened, or a bad thing if it does happen, nobody knows for sure, but the most important thing is that it doesn't really matter if it does or not.Yes, there's plenty of potential on offer for a successful sequel, but I'll leave that to people's imagination regarding the story for a sequel."The Goonies" is one of these many movies you could watch again and again, yet still not get bored of it. It's a great adventure...

Four kids named Mikey (Sean Astin), Chunk (Jeff Cohen), Mouth (Corey Feldman) and Data (Ke Huy Quan) who call themselves "The Goonies" finds a map in the attic of Mikey's house. Their beloved neighborhood is about to become a golf course, so they go out on an adventure to find lost buried treasure. Unfortunately three crooks Mama Fratelli (Anne Ramsey) with her sons Jake (Robert Davi) and Francis (Joe Pantoliano) are also seeking the treasure.One of the most beloved movies of the 80's! this outstanding adventure from director Richard Donner and producer Steven Spielberg has made a hilarious and entertaining film for all ages. The film co-stars Josh Brolin in his debut as Brand whom is Mikey's big tough brother, beautiful Keri Green as hottie Andi and the lovable deformed man Sloth played by John Matsuzak all give good performances.This movie still holds up as a modern cult classic that has been embraced over the years, this is a must see.

You can really see where Stranger Things has gotten so much of their inspiration from. The Goonies perfectly captures that wonder and sense of adventure that childhood offers. It's a wonderful and charming film that still holds up over 30 years later.

The Goonies is a fantastic children movie. Jeff Cohen is simply the most hilarious kid I have ever seen in a movie, without a doubt, Sean Astin's one of the most successful movie. This is probably one of the most finest kid films that's not animated!! Richard Donner and Steven Spielberg did very well in making this a class act movie with highly supportive fans that could talk about this day and day. You will also laugh your head off at most of the characters like Jeff Cohen and the Chinese inventor kid. There are also memorable lines that are still talked about today. The Goonies is very impressive and you will have a very fun time watching it.9/10

The stage curtains open ...I'm always a little apprehensive in reviewing such good movies, like this one, because I'm afraid my reviews won't do them justice. Such is the case with "The Goonies", this classic film from 1985 - which was such an integral part of my teenage years growing up.The story starts out with a tight group of friends, who call themselves the Goonies, spending what is to be their last Saturday together - since they are all about to lose their homes due to foreclosures and have to move to different towns and cities. They want to go out with a bang, so they decide to follow a map they found among some pirate relics in an attic, leading to the hidden treasure of One-Eyed Willy, the greatest pirate of his time. Along the way, they come across the secret hideout of the Fratelli's - a notorious gang on the run from the law. With the Fratelli's on their tail, they endure exciting dangers in tunnels underground while learning the value of friendship, reliance and loss as they try to save their homes and way of life.This movie carries with it some very strong sentimental attachments for me, as I was the same age as most of the Goonies were when the film first came out.. The characters almost became like friends to me: Mikey, Brand, Chunk, Mouth, Data, Andy, Stef ... and even Sloth. With names like those, you know it has to be a fun movie.I can't give this film any higher rating or recommend. Yes, you have to suspend disbelief and just let yourself be entertained. It is a fantasy, yet extremely funny - and it still holds up well even today. I watch it at least once a year, sometimes more, and I can quote the entire movie - line for line (but don't worry, if you were ever to watch this movie with me, I wouldn't actually do that since I know how annoying it can be). This is a classic! One of the best of its kind.

Review title: Fun for the nostalgic, very poor for a rated film
Review_body: This Spielberg written, directed and produced mid-80's action/fantasy quickly became a cinema classic. "Hey you guys", the chase for a treasure, those iconic kid characters... but really for a neutral, this film provides some fun; at times pretty good; for about the first hour...after which the film runs out of puff is merely sets out to complete the storyline and bundle it up in cheesy typical Hollywood fashion.This is Spielberg making money, not Spielberg making art. Come up with an ultra-simple plot, execute it with enough effort that it's watchable but by no means great, stereotypical characters who fulfill their roles, play the teen element (as was the new trend during those days), a couple adventure with humor. Big production. Bam. Major success. Onto the next one.

Ok I am 48 years old I have watched 1000s Of Film's. The Goonies is my all time Favorite I have no idea why. Probably because me and my Buddies WANTED TO BE A GOONIE LOL. This is One of the BEST FILMS EVER MADE SO HOLLYWOOD DO NOT REMAKE THIS FILM. JUST LEAVE IT ALONE PLEASE. It is Fantastic the way it is.

It's been over 30 years since I last watched The Goonies. We had a copy on well worn VHS that came out of its box most weekends. You'd think then that I'd remember it well. The gist yes, but the details have been erased, which is what makes reliving it so much fun. It's not a great film, but it's different when you discover something as a child, the quality doesn't matter as much, it's something that speaks to you regardless. Now I grew up in Manchester, far from this seemingly exciting American suburb on the screen. The kids think their town is boring, but to me it was another world. One with big unusual looking houses, wide streets, bikes and adventure. Oh boy the adventure, the Spielberg kind (credited as a co-writer, but his stamp is all over it), wondrous and over the top. The Goonies live in a space without parents, although their escapades are in aid of them, but the screen time is all theirs, misfit kids on a treasure trail intent on making the most of "our time". Cue hefty doses of slapstick, teen movie tropes, booby traps, a rousing fantasy score and smaltzy sentimentality. I'd be lying if I said I enjoyed this as much as I did when I was a kid, but honestly it was close, it really stands up, good clean full blown fun. Childhood wonder should never leave you and Goonies... never die.

Funny movie. I really enjoyed watching the movie. The characters of the movie were great except for Data which was just fun at the beginning of the movie and after that it got really annoying and Andy was annoying. Chunk was the best character in the movie.

There must've been at least one or two kids in every household who would punch the hell out of you if you'd never saw "The Goonies" or know some of the scenes and characters. I was one of those household kids who cherish this 1985 classic as if watching "Raiders of the Lost Ark" as a kid where every weekend when I didn't need to do homework, one of my favorite eighties classics would be playing in the VCR from Ghostbusters, Goonies or Raiders of the Lost Ark.The Goonies is about a group of four young boys who are considered losers and outcasts to the popular kids. Mike (Sean Astin) is the leader of the group where he's always being teased and corrected in conversation by his older brother Brandon (Josh Brolin) who's trying to fit in with others. Mike's friend include a chatterbox know-it-all name Mouth (Corey Feldman), an inventor and James Bond fanatic Data (Jonathan Ke Quan), and chubby and great liar Chuck (Jeff Cohan). Mike and Brandon are upset that a group of rich snobs have seized the property of their parents house along with the rest of the community where all the houses and docks are going to be tear down for a country club to be made. Mike and his friends investigate the attic with Brandon where they try to seek any hidden treasures around the city before tying up Mike's brother.There is a subplot behind this comedy caper where the group of boys see that other people are at an abandon building with the treasure being hidden inside. More things are hidden inside as well before Brandon rescues Mike and others for any huge embarrassment. New characters enter from pop tart cheerleader Andy (Kerri Green) to geeky Stephanie (Martha Plimpton) who not only know Brandon and the kids but get involve with them as well with one thing happening over the next."The Goonies" is a funny movie where despite a few harsh languages here and there, especially the young kids saying a four letter S word (and I don't mean suck), there's nothing offensive about it.
This takes you on such an adventure and has all the elements of film you can watch no matter what age you are.

Goonies... Where do I begin? This movie is the ultimate tressure hunt for one eyed willies gold. An amazing movie if I must say, many well known actors of the 80s, I love the plot, the comedy, the music, literally everything about it is spot on.Definitely watch this if you haven't already, even if you have its worth another ain't it :)
This is a great film whether it's all the family or just watching on your own. Excellent fun.

Review title: A fun revisit to an 80's kids classic
Review_body: Reliving childhood films at times, rediscovers a familiar part of you forgotten!

Why did I wait so long before watching this movie? If I had seen this movie as a kid my imagination would have gone wild. When I was younger, I was always into the whole Treasure Hunting thing, always making clues and hiding them and having other's find them. The Goonies is basically a treasure hunt, and it's a damn good one too. I watched this mostly just because people were saying how great it was, and how it was one of the movies that inspired one of my favorite films from last year "Super 8." Well before I praise this movie, first let me say a few things that bothered me.The character of Chunk, the fat kid, doesn't go in the caves with the rest of the group, and in the last act, we barely see him. Which is a shame. Also some parts seemed a little too adult, I could handle the skeletons, but I can't really see why they put in the scene with the statue's genitals falling off. Also Data's accent got annoying at times, he sounds like Short Round from "Temple of Doom." But this movie really put a smile on my face, it's a classic adventure movie about finding a treasure. Like I said, I loved that stuff when I was younger, so this really brought a nostalgia feeling. The characters are great, sure they all fit into a stereotype: fat, Asian, cool, leader, but they all are so funny and likable. I like that they have both kids and teenagers on this journey. That way more people can relate. The villains are great, and the film had me laughing tons of times. I could say more, but I assume most of you have seen this film, and if you haven't, go watch it.The Goonies isn't quite as good as E.T., Close Encounters, or Super 8, but it's still a fun, nostalgic, and very funny ride. I will be buying this as soon as I can and it will go right on my shelf along with those other three.
The goonies it is a really good old movie. It is a classic. It has adventure, action and comedy.

Great, uneven masterpiece which resembles the work of Spielberg and Lucas. For example this movie reminds me a lot of the epic computer game "Maniac Mansion" because of the character of the kids and the weirdos in the old house. I grew up in the 1980s, and I still remember the scary scenes with the freak in the basement who eats chocolate. For some reason, it touched me a lot, that he was so hungry and starving. I just watched it again on DVD, and it is still pretty good, although somewhat uneven. I think it would have been even better if it had taken place in an old house or a forest or something, instead of the set-like tunnels it actually takes place in. However, the story and energy of the movie is so amazing that one cannot help like it. It is like other great 80s movies such as "Back to the Future" a great description of that particular generation.

Tonight's movie review is in memory of the great Richard Donner the man who was behind the awesomeness Lethal Weapon series, Scrooged, Conspiracy Theory and the timeless movie Superman. Since this review is paying tribute, tonight's movie review will be children epic adventure The Goonies (1985). Believe it or not this is my first time watching this film this past week and since then I have gone back and forth to question why this particular flick has influenced so many shows and movies including Stranger Things.The story to me is straightforward, what would a bunch of bored kids get up to on a rainy day? Well, in this case, they settled on an adventure to find hidden pirate treasure whilst evading a bickering family of Italian mobsters known as the Fratelli's. The kids are from a blue-collar "Goon Docks" district of Astoria, Oregon and a bunch of them are trying to figure out how to save their homes from demolition. When the kids find a map written in Spanish which will lead to pirate treasure, they use the motto of "our time" and go onto an epic underground cave adventure. The treasure belongs to the infamous pirate, One Eyed Willy.The film itself starts with a Jolly Roger symbol then a jailbreak and a car chase which has a throwback to the 1930s and 1940s slap stick chasing where the homage is the Spanish housemaid in the middle of the road of a car chase. We see heaps of 60s to 80s throwbacks including the iconic Prince's Purple Rain printed t-shirt worn by 80s child actor Corey Haim and the James Bond theme played while the character Data uses his gadgets to swing from house to house. All this is good and all but there are some mirky weird remarks including the statue reference - why?? And the supposedly funny translation from English to Spanish scene - again not so childlike for a kid's movie. There is one thing I have noticed in the film, the lack of diverse characters. And this isn't getting woke or anything, it was just weird only seeing every specific stereotype except for one diverse family.The movie itself is okay and has some cool parts including the cave waterslide part - any kids true dream to get on that slide and fly mid-air into a pool of water in the end. The scene where the Andy has to play the correct notes on a a skeleton style organ was cool as. There are some coming of age scenes including the pash between Andy and Mikey and Andy and the older brother Brand. All the kids are great and do an awesome part in the film. The scene stealer to me is Chunk, our typical American kid who loves to eat and loves action and is a klutz. Plus, his interrogation and confession scenes were hilarious. The villains in this film are great and the one who really stole the show to me is Anne Ramsey, including her determined look chasing the kids in the cave to telling Corey's character Mouth whether he would like to eat tongue after he was ordering a few Italian dishes. Sean Astin as Mikey was cool and showed that it doesn't matter if you have an asthma pump when you are a kid, you can still achieve anything. And of course, you have you have Sloth, every child's hope that monster lookalikes are in fact good wholesome individuals. Plus, he was wearing a Superman t-shirt.This plus the Cyndi Lauper rack of "The Goonies 'r' Good Enough" were a good mix and yes I did watch the Cyndi Lauper clip and it was weird as much as the film where colourful pirates are chasing Cyndi with a sheik in the background is impatiently waiting to demolish a family home. Plus, you have the Hibachi scene!!Going back to the film we see retro kids riding their bikes with mates, seeing a teenager reading guns and ammo in the restroom and a first kiss. But to me this isn't a classic 80s kids film. At best a once or twice over, not a cult classic to me but it's still a good time, overall 7/10.

This film is suitable for children and their parents. Firstly, the plot is simple, it's something between "It" and "Home alone". Secondly, the cast is good, Josh Brolin is very young and plays typical older brother. Sean Astin plays person who leads others to treasure trough dangers. Sound very familiar, don't it? (he also plays Sam in LOTR).
So, it's good family film for evening.

Review title: "The Goonies"'s vision of childhood is flawed, but not so Spielberg and Donner's flair for spectacle
Review_body: The children who constitute the Goonies only really exist in the mind of Steven Spielberg, who produced and created the story. He sees boy children as fast-talking, fun-loving, dream-chasing rascals. Girl children older than, say, Drew Barrymore in "E.T." are valuable as targets and instigators of boys' sexual precociousness, but are mostly just taggers-along on boys' adventures.
